entry.title: bitcoin.org missing bitcoin core version 22.0
entry.summary:
The discussion revolves around the commendation of a strategy aimed at decentralizing control and reducing reliance on single points of failure, commonly referred to as decreasing the bus factor. This approach is deemed sensible and beneficial for fostering a more resilient and distributed system of development or governance. A key piece of advice given is the importance of building one's own release, which underscores the value of self-sufficiency and the empowerment of individuals within the community. However, it comes with a cautionary note to always verify the tree hash when doing so. This verification process is critical for ensuring the integrity and authenticity of the codebase, safeguarding against potential tampering or malicious alterations.
Moreover, the conversation highlights the significance of trusting signed annotated tags. These tags serve as a secure method for marking specific points in the repository's history, indicating official releases or significant updates. The use of such tags adds an additional layer of security, helping to ensure that the code being used or contributed to is legitimate and has been duly vetted by trusted members of the community.
For further reading and a deeper understanding of the principles discussed, a link is provided: [decentralize decisions](https://laanwj.github.io/2021/01/21/decentralize.html). This resource offers insights into the rationale behind decentralizing decision-making processes and the practical steps that can be taken to achieve this goal. It serves as a valuable guide for those interested in contributing to or leading projects with a decentralized ethos, emphasizing the need for careful verification and trust in digital signatures to maintain the integrity and trustworthiness of the project.
